text: Standard 1: VISUAL ARTS—Understand and apply art materials, techniques, and processes in the creation of original works of art and understand how the visual arts communicate a variety of ideas, feelings, and experiences

children.text: HOW THE ARTS ARE ORGANIZED
Use developmentally appropriate art vocabulary
Use developmentally appropriate art media, tools, and processes
Use various types of art media
Use the elements of line, shape, form, texture, color, and the principles of repetition and variety in artwork using a variety of art mediums
Differentiate between two-dimensional and three-dimensional artwork
Demonstrate how mixing primary colors can create secondary colors
Use the element of space and the principles of repetition and variety, with a variety of art media
Use the elements and principles of art and design, including, value (i.e., tints and shades, analogous colors), line, rhythm, movement, proportion, and balance
Use a variety of art and technology media to create an original work of art
Use the elements and principles of art and design, such as emphasis, proportion, complementary colors, positive and negative space, and depth, to communicate an idea or mood
Use a combination of visual and performing arts to create an original artwork
Use the principles of art and design, including unity and harmony, in works of art
Analyze, using evidence, the element of space (perspective, overlapping, foreground, background) and how it is developed in works of art
Analyze, using evidence, the characteristics of representational and/or non-representational art
Create an original integrated art product or performance and explain how this process enhances a specific art work
Apply selected elements and principles of art and design to communicate a particular message or opinion in an original work of art
Use art vocabulary when evaluating intent and content of works of art
Create original works of art using a variety of visual arts materials, techniques, and processes
Demonstrate how the composition of a work of art is affected by the use of elements or principles of art and design
Analyze, using evidence, the relationship between themes explored in the visual arts and those explored in other content areas
HOW THE ARTS COMMUNICATE
Create art that expresses feelings about a familiar subject
Explain preferences for particular works of art
Use familiar subjects and experiences to create original works of art
Use color to convey mood in works of art
Describe different responses to the same work of art
Use observational skills in creating an original work of art
Use visual arts vocabulary to discuss and compare works of art
Use properties, personal response, and research to make informed judgments about artwork
Explain how an original artwork demonstrates a concept or idea from another discipline
Apply different qualities and characteristics of art materials, techniques, and processes to convey effectively different experiences, ideas, and opinions
Describe how different elements and principles of art and design and styles can be used to express a variety of moods, feelings, themes, and ideas
Use subjects, themes, or symbols from life experiences to convey personal ideas
Evaluate the effectiveness of the use of elements and principles of art and design in works of art
Create works of art that contain one or more symbols, themes, and metaphors
HOW THE ARTS SHAPE AND REFLECT CULTURE
Explain the concept that all artwork is meant to be appreciated and some artwork is also meant to be useful
Compare artwork from various cultures that have similar themes and subject matter
Investigate how art is used in celebrations, festivals, and customs of selected cultures from the past and present
Compare themes and subject matter in works of art from different time periods
Explain how art reflects life, culture, attitudes, and beliefs of the artist
Analyze works of art from selected historical periods
Compare works of art from various regions of the United States
Compare the characteristics of artwork from various historical periods and/or cultures
Analyze, using evidence, how cultural factors have affected works of art now and in the past
Analyze, using evidence, why specific works of art were created
Evaluate the function of artwork in different cultures, careers, and historical periods
Analyze common characteristics of works of art and artifacts across time periods and among cultural groups to identify influences

text: Standard 2: MUSIC—Understand and apply elements of music and understand how music communicates ideas, feelings, and experiences across cultures

children.text: HOW THE ARTS ARE ORGANIZED
Use singing voice to echo short melodic patterns in appropriate range
Demonstrate simple representation of high and low, short and long, loud and soft, fast and slow
Use simple patterns of rhythm and pitch using quarter notes, quarter rest, and eighth notes
Use the notations for four-beat rhythmic patterns using quarter notes, quarter rests, and eighth notes
Use a four-beat melodic or rhythmic pattern to demonstrate the simple musical form of "echo"
Recognize, by sound quality, various characteristics of instruments and vocal sounds
Sing a simple song with appropriate vocal range from memory
Identify families of instruments and how each sound is produced
Demonstrate rhythmic notation of whole notes, half notes, quarter notes, eighth notes and quarter rests
Use melodic notation of simple four-beat patterns using three different pitches on a staff
Use the notation of whole, half, quarter, eighth, dotted-half notes, and rests
Read the notes of a "C" major scale on a staff
Identify simple musical forms and melodic or rhythmic ostinato (repeated) pattern
Identify the basic instruments of the orchestra by sight, sound, and category (e.g., brass, woodwind, percussion, strings)
Sing rounds and partner songs from memory
Compare elements of music, such as form, pattern, or rhythm, to other art forms
Create short rhythmic and melodic phrases using two to four measure phrases and five different pitches on a staff
Read simple staff notation (e.g., key signature, time signature, clef)
Use notation of sixteenth notes and rests
Sing or play an independent part of a song with two or more parts
Identify musical forms (e.g., rondos), theme, and variations
Use notation of dotted rhythms with dotted quarter and dotted eighths
Perform an accompaniment for a piece of music
Use music of various styles/genres in performances
Integrate several arts disciplines into a presentation or performance
Perform a variety of musical elements (e.g., tone, rhythm) with understanding and accuracy
Perform music from a variety of cultures, styles, and genres individually as well as in small and/or large ensembles
Compose, arrange, or notate music using specified guidelines
Improvise a short pattern or melody to be performed with a rhythmic and/or melodic accompaniment
Compare terms and elements used in music, the other arts, and other content areas
Perform music in various meters
Perform a variety of musical elements with appropriate understanding, expression and style individually and in a group
Improvise short melodies based on a chord pattern
Apply knowledge of music theory to compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
Analyze compositional devices and techniques
HOW THE ARTS COMMUNICATE
Use an instrument to maintain a steady beat using quarter notes and quarter rests
Explain how music can communicate ideas and moods
Sing or play repeating rhythmic or melodic patterns
Use specific musical terms to respond to elements of a musical performance
Develop criteria used to analyze a musical performance
Analyze musical elements when explaining or critiquing a musical selection or musical performance
Evaluate the effectiveness of a musical performance or composition
Critique music using specific criteria
HOW THE ARTS SHAPE AND REFLECT CULTURE
Identify various sources of music that can be heard in daily life and their purpose
Compare music used for special occasions from various cultures
Describe instrument families and sounds from various cultures
Identify developmentally appropriate pieces of music representing various time periods
Perform songs from various cultures within their cultural context
Compare and contrast musical styles from two or more cultures
Compare the use of musical elements in aural examples of American music and in music from other cultures
Compare the role of music and composers in various cultures and time periods
Analyze the use of musical elements in various cultures with an emphasis on melody and harmonic progressions
Describe how various elements and roles of music integrate with other content areas
Analyze the significance of music and composers in various cultures and time periods

text: Standard 3: DRAMA AND THEATRE—Understand and apply the skills of acting, design, and technical theatre and understand the role of drama in various cultures throughout history

children.text: HOW THE ARTS ARE ORGANIZED
Perform imitative movements
Recognize theatrical vocabulary
Adapt and dramatize a familiar story
Use physical movements, rhythms, and voice, to express simple feelings, character, and plot
Create simple costumes, scenery, and props
Create a dramatization based on a story
Interpret a character's external motivations
Create a class dramatization by collaborating as actors, directors, scriptwriters, and technical artists
Perform various roles and responsibilities in theatre productions
Develop dialogue for a scene or one-act play
Apply basic stage movement
Design scenery that establishes an environment for a character
Create a script or scene incorporating characters, dialogue, scenery, props, costumes, lighting, and sound
Use collaboration and revision to develop and produce a play or scene
HOW THE ARTS COMMUNICATE
Explain how theatrical performances often cause emotional reactions
Evaluate personal feelings about a theatrical work
Critique characterization in a theatrical work
Interpret the ideas and morals of theatrical works
Use appropriate audience etiquette while listening and watching a theatrical performance
Use the elements of theatre to create a critique of a theatrical performance
Use the voice to express emotion
Dramatize an historical event or social issue
Analyze a character using knowledge of performance and acting skills in a theatrical production
Demonstrate how theatre can be used to communicate concepts from another content area
Explain the effect and impact of sets, make-up, costumes, sound, light, and props in a theatrical performance
Evaluate the use of technical elements (e.g., sets, makeup, costumes, sound and light, props) and their effect on the meaning of the production
Demonstrate various elements that contribute to the overall impact of a theatrical presentation on an audience
Analyze the physical, emotional, and social dimensions of characters in texts and performances
Implement artistic choices for informal and formal productions
Develop and apply criteria to critique all aspects of a live theatrical production
Assess the role of the audience in relation to the overall live theatrical experience
HOW THE ARTS SHAPE AND REFLECT CULTURE
Demonstrate how cultures have used dramatic play to express human experience
Analyze the dramatic elements of culture that exist in stories, songs, fairy tales, fables, and nursery rhymes
Assess how various styles of theatrical production relate to culture
Compare similar dramatic themes between works from various cultures
Evaluate theatrical traditions of various cultures
Analyze, using evidence, the role of dramatic productions which are part of American history
Explain the role of an audience in a theatrical production
Compare theatrical styles common to certain historical and cultural periods
Apply theatrical traditions of various cultures
Explain how theatre has depicted the history of America
Evaluate how technology has impacted theatre production
Apply period style to dramatic forms, production practices, and theatrical traditions from various cultures and historical periods

text: Standard 4: DANCE—Understand and apply elements of dance, appreciate how dance communicates meaning, and recognize its role across cultures and throughout history

children.text: HOW THE ARTS ARE ORGANIZED
Use body, energy, space, and time to move in different ways
Create a dance that consists of a beginning, middle, and end
Apply the element of space (e.g., place, size, level, direction) to create simple movement sequences
Apply the element of energy – smooth/sharp (attack), heavy/light (weight), tight/loose (flow) – to create simple movement sequences
Repeat a simple movement sequence by imitation
Apply the element of space and pathways to create simple movement sequences
Demonstrate the element of time, tempo, beat, duration, and rhythm
Use simple partner skills during movement sequences
Apply dance elements to create a simple movement sequence
Combine dance elements to create a simple dance with a partner or small group
Modify a simple dance using the elements of dance
Use simple dance forms
Explain how the elements of dance relate to elements of other art forms
Use kinesthetic awareness, concentration, and focus in performing movement skills
Apply the use of choreographic principles with partners or in groups
Use a variety of dance elements to develop dance phrases
Use a variety of choreographic structures or forms to develop movement studies
Use kinesthetic awareness and spatial awareness in combination with time or force elements
Use all of the dance elements in creating dance sequences
Demonstrate choreographic principles, processes, and structures
Analyze the effect of lifestyle choices on a dancer
Synthesize dance with other disciplines
HOW THE ARTS COMMUNICATE
Create movements that represent ideas, persons, and places
Use movement to respond to a variety of stimuli, such as observed dance, words, sounds and songs
Describe how an idea is communicated through dance
Create movement sequences that express a mood
Explain personal interpretations of a variety of dances
Create simple dances that communicate abstract ideas or feelings
Justify personal opinions and interpretations of works of dance
Use criteria to assess the quality of a dance performance
Evaluate a dance for dance elements, choreographic principles, processes, and structures
Evaluate a dance using personal preferences and personal knowledge of dance composition and impact
Communicate daily life experiences and ideas through dance
Use movement choices to communicate abstract ideas in dance
HOW THE ARTS SHAPE AND REFLECT CULTURE
Perform a folk/traditional dance from another culture
Describe the role of dance from a variety of cultures
Compare dances from a variety of cultures
Perform dance movements of different styles (e.g. ballet, jazz), cultures, and time periods
Describe how the dances of Hawaii reflect the Hawaiian history and culture
Analyze American dances from different periods of history
Compare types of dances from different cultures and historical periods
Analyze the historical evolution of dance from the lives of people in a community over time
Apply complex steps and patterns of dances from a number of styles, genres, and cultures
